The famed Duke Ellington and has jazz orchestra
will present a Commemoration Day concert here in Shriver
Hall Monday, February 22, at 8:30 p.m.
According to an announcement this week-by Chester
Wickwire, YMCA Executive Secretary, tickets for the
Ellington concert are priced at $2.50 and $3.00 and are
being put on sale today in the YMCA office in Levering
Hall. Other points for distribution of tickets will be
established soon.
Dr. Wickwire explained that the February .22 date
is particularly good as there are no classes that day
(Commemoration Day) and therefore the parking problem will not interfere.
Carnegie Hall
Ellington, who has been described as America's foremost jazz composer and bandleader, has played in major
concert halls throughout the United States since he became the first big band leader to play in New York's
Carnegie Hall. He has since played at the Philharmonic

By MARK PEREL
It is fair to say that any musically conscious person at the
Hopkins would probably jump at
the chance nowadays to be able
to hear classical music on campus, particularly now that the
listening facilities of the Goodwille Room have been deprived
us. Such an assertion is substantiated by the size of the
audience which nearly filled
Shriver Hall Sunday to greet the
Baltimore Symphony Orchestra
under its conductor, Peter Herman Adler. To be sure, there was
a quantity of music, but this
deprived music lover found little
quality, either technically or
interpretively.
Obviously designed for speaking, Shriver's acoustics would
flatter no orchestra; they are dry
and unpleasant, and limited the
orchestra's dynamic range to
somewhere between piano and
mezzo-forte during the entire
concert.

Writer Sums Up Dr. Rowell Gives Program

The second presentation under
the auspices of Goucher-Hopkins
will
Coordination
Committee
take place Thursday, February
11, when the Maryland Alpha
Chapter of Tau Beta Pi sponsors
a talk by Goucher President Dr.
Otto Kraushaar in the Levering
Hall Sherwood Room.
Dr. Kraushaar is thus reciprocating for the visit JHU President Milton Eisenhower paid
Goucher in the first coordinated
effort earlier this month.
The number-one
man at
Goucher "would like to have an
informal discussion with a small
group of students from both
schools on the subject 'Values of
College Student,' according to a
statement from the committee.
Due to the limited number of
students 'who will be allowed to
attend the meeting, Tau Beta Pi
has decided to pick them by a
"random" system of selection.
All those interested in attending

have been asked to submit their
name, box number and whether
or not they have a car that can
be used to transport Goucher
girls to Hopkins, to either Doug
Gaasterland, box 2256 or Jim
Kallis, box 467.
Goucher also has announced
that Hopkins students are invited to attend a special 75th anniversary program on "Human
Values in the Emerging American City" at Goucher College,
which will feature five speakers,
on January 25 and February 23,
Speakers listed are Pietro Belluschi, Dean of the School of
Architecture and Planning at
M.I.T., Alfred Kazin, author and
former professor of American
Studies at Amherst College, and
Mark Shubart, Dean of the Juillard School of Music and former
Music Editor of The New York
Times.

The Johns Hopkins Playshop
will present its second Drama
Evening of the school year on
Sunday night when Dr. Henry
T. Rowell, professor of classics
at the University, will deliver a
lecture on "Greek and Latin
Comedy," which will be followed
by an illustrative presentation of
"The Arbitration," by Menander.
The program, under the auspices of the Amos Taylor, Jr.,
Memorial Lecture series, will be
held in Shriver Hall auditorium
beginning at 8:30 p.m.
The program comes under the
term of a Drama Evening by
reason of its two-sided look at
the art of the theater—a lecture
followed by acted scenes from a
play.

scripts) by members of the Playshop, aided by several undergraduates. Ed Ross, president of

By MARK PEREL
It is fair to say that any musically conscious person at the
Hopkins would probably jump at
the chance nowadays to be able
to hear classical music on campus, particularly now that the
listening facilities of the Goodwille Room have been deprived
us. Such an assertion is substantiated by the size of the
audience which nearly filled
Shriver Hall Sunday to greet the
Baltimore Symphony Orchestra
under its conductor, Peter Herman Adler. To be sure, there was
a quantity of music, but this
deprived music lover found little
quality, either technically or
interpretively.
Obviously designed for speaking, Shriver's acoustics would
flatter no orchestra; they are dry
and unpleasant, and limited the
orchestra's dynamic range to
somewhere between piano and
mezzo-forte during the entire
concert.

The second presentation under
the auspices of Goucher-Hopkins
will
Coordination
Committee
take place Thursday, February
11, when the Maryland Alpha
Chapter of Tau Beta Pi sponsors
a talk by Goucher President Dr.
Otto Kraushaar in the Levering
Hall Sherwood Room.
Dr. Kraushaar is thus reciprocating for the visit JHU President Milton Eisenhower paid
Goucher in the first coordinated
effort earlier this month.
The number-one
man at
Goucher "would like to have an
informal discussion with a small
group of students from both
schools on the subject 'Values of
College Student,' according to a
statement from the committee.
Due to the limited number of
students 'who will be allowed to
attend the meeting, Tau Beta Pi
has decided to pick them by a
"random" system of selection.
All those interested in attending

have been asked to submit their
name, box number and whether
or not they have a car that can
be used to transport Goucher
girls to Hopkins, to either Doug
Gaasterland, box 2256 or Jim
Kallis, box 467.
Goucher also has announced
that Hopkins students are invited to attend a special 75th anniversary program on "Human
Values in the Emerging American City" at Goucher College,
which will feature five speakers,
on January 25 and February 23,
Speakers listed are Pietro Belluschi, Dean of the School of
Architecture and Planning at
M.I.T., Alfred Kazin, author and
former professor of American
Studies at Amherst College, and
Mark Shubart, Dean of the Juillard School of Music and former
Music Editor of The New York
Times.

The Johns Hopkins Playshop
will present its second Drama
Evening of the school year on
Sunday night when Dr. Henry
T. Rowell, professor of classics
at the University, will deliver a
lecture on "Greek and Latin
Comedy," which will be followed
by an illustrative presentation of
"The Arbitration," by Menander.
The program, under the auspices of the Amos Taylor, Jr.,
Memorial Lecture series, will be
held in Shriver Hall auditorium
beginning at 8:30 p.m.
The program comes under the
term of a Drama Evening by
reason of its two-sided look at
the art of the theater—a lecture
followed by acted scenes from a
play.
Dr. Rowell's lecture will be followed by scenes acted (with
scripts) by members of the Playshop, aided by several undergraduates. Ed Ross, president of
